column1: Lebedyan (Russian: Лебедя́нь) is a town and the administrative center of Lebedyansky District in Lipetsk Oblast
column3: located on the upper Don River
column5: the administrative center of the oblast. Population: 21

column1: It was founded in 1613 largely to guard the holdings of I. N. Romanov
column3: and served as a border outpost protecting South Russia from the Crimean Tatars' incursions. The Trinity Monastery was established in 1621 and several churches were built by the end of the century; they are all now reduced to ruins.

column2: Lebedyan developed in the 19th century as a center of horse racing and horse breeding. The locals claim that the first racetrack in Russia was opened here in 1826. The Agricultural Society of Lebedyan
column4: was influential in preparing the emancipation reform of 1861.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Lebedyan serves as the administrative center of Lebedyansky District. As an administrative division
column3: it is incorporated within Lebedyansky District as Lebedyan Town Under District Jurisdiction. As a municipal division
column4: Lebedyan Town Under District Jurisdiction is incorporated within Lebedyansky Municipal District as Lebedyan Urban Settlement.

column1: The town is the location of the largest fruit juice manufacturer in Eastern Europe

column2: both dedicated to the icon of the Theotokos of Kazan. The old and neglected cathedral goes back to the 18th century
column3: while the larger cathedral on the market square was designed in the Empire style and consecrated in 1839.

column1: Lebedyan is the birthplace of Yevgeny Zamyatin. Other residents of the town include Mikhail Bulgakov and Andrey Bely. Ivan Turgenev incorporated a story titled Lebedyan in his collection A Sportsman's Sketches. It was also the home of Leonid Mulyarchik
column2: who attempted to singlehandedly build a subway system in the town. (He eventually gave up on the project.)
